docs.lead_paragraph: In hindsight, it should probably come as little surprise to Democrats that voters in Massachusetts, a state with universal access to health insurance, would not feel all that motivated to rescue President Obama's efforts to provide similar benefits nationwide. Massachusetts has the lowest proportion of uninsured residents of any state in the nation -- just 5.2 percent, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation -- thanks to the state's 2006 universal health care law, which the winner in Tuesday's special election, Scott Brown, supported as a Republican state senator and which was signed by Gov. Mitt Romney, also a Republican.

headline.main: A State With Less to Lose

docs.abstract: Massachusetts residents have access to universal health insurance, which may explain why voters in Senate special election did not feel motivated to rescue Pres Obama's efforts to provide similar benefits nationwide; state's 2006 universal health care law was supported by Scott Brown, then Republican state senator, and signed by Mitt Romney, Republican governor; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In hindsight, it should probably come as little surprise to Democrats that voters in Massachusetts, a state with universal access to health insurance, would not feel all that motivated to rescue President Obama's efforts to provide similar benefits...

docs.lead_paragraph: The results of the Senate election Tuesday in Massachusetts have been widely interpreted as a sudden indictment of Democratic health care legislation. Yet a spate of recent national polls signal that little has changed over the last six months: Americans have remained divided over the proposals without significant shifts. Over all, most of the latest polls show more Americans oppose the health care changes being debated in Washington, but the most recent survey finds an even split.
docs.abstract: Scott Brown's upset victory in Senate election in Massachusetts has been widely interpreted as indictment of Democratic health care legislation, but recent national polls indicate public opinion remains almost evenly divided over proposals and has not shifted significantly (M)
docs.snippet: The results of the Senate election Tuesday in Massachusetts have been widely interpreted as a sudden indictment of Democratic health care legislation. Yet a spate of recent national polls signal that little has changed over the last six months:...
